ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

WATER DISTRIBUTION PIPES ON ROOF TOPS OF HDB BLOCKS
(Insulation)


    1. Mr Cheo Chai Chen asked the Acting Minister for National Development, besides painting white heat-proof paint on the pipes, what steps the Housing and

Column: 514

Development Board has taken to adequately insulate water distribution pipes on the roof tops of HDB blocks so as to prevent the water supply from becoming uncomfortably hot.

     The Acting Minister for National Development (Mr Lim Hng Kiang): Mr Speaker, Sir, the problem of hot water is faced mainly by residents on the two top most storeys of HDB blocks, as these residents are served by separate water mains which are exposed to the sun. The water in these mains, which serve fewer units, is heated up faster compared with those in the main water mains.

    To reduce the amount of heat absorption, HDB has painted all the water pipes in existing blocks with white paint. This has been found to be the simplest and most cost-effective way of lowering the water temperature. There have been few complaints of the hot water problem after this measure was taken.

    For new HDB flats, HDB has successfully experimented with the use of UPVC half-round channels to cover the water distribution mains. This has been implemented in all new building contracts tendered from 1st September 1992 onwards.

Column: 514

ALLOCATION OF HDB FLATS
(New rulings to balance interest of first-timers and upgraders)


    2. Dr Kanwaljit Soin asked the Acting Minister for National Development what new rulings the Housing and Development Board intends to implement in the allocation of flats to balance the interests of first-timers and upgraders.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Mr Speaker, Sir, HDB has finalised its review of the allocation system for new flats to balance the interests of first-time applicants and upgraders. I will announce details of the review later on.

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin (Nominated Member): Sir, would the Minister agree that it is the Government's responsibility to provide housing for first-timers and, after that, it

Column: 515

should be left to market forces and that we should not subsidise upgraders at the expense of other taxpayers?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Mr Speaker, Sir, that is not the current Government policy. Government does provide housing for first-time applicants as well as provide the facility for upgraders to upgrade to a new and better flat.

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin: Would the Minister explain the rationale of subsidising upgraders? Would that not be considered a handout?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Sir, the Government encourages Singaporeans to upgrade because this is part of the asset enhancement programme.

Column: 515

PAP COMMUNITY FOUNDATION KINDERGARTENS
AT POTONG PASIR CONSTITUENCY


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Chiam See Tong -

    3. To ask the Acting Minister for National Development whether the Housing and Development Board premises at Block 143, Potong Pasir Avenue 2 and at Blocks 211 and 213, Lorong 8, Toa Payoh, which are now occupied by the PAP Community Foundation kindergartens, can be taken over either by the Potong Pasir Town Council or by a church/charitable group to operate similar kindergartens there, if the PAP Community Foundation carries out its announced intention not to run the kindergartens in 1995.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Question No. 3, Sir.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Mr Speaker, Sir, HDB lets out Education Centres only to approved Foundations which are registered under section 29 of the Companies Act with a minimum paid-up capital of $5 million and are recommended by the Advisor to the Citizens' Consultative Committee. Town Councils do not have the mandate to run education centres. It

Column: 516

would be possible for a church or charitable group to operate the education centres if it registers itself as a Foundation with the minimum paid-up capital.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: The question is: if the PAP Community Foundation (PCF) should withdraw, would the HDB allow a charitable organisation to run the education centre at the said premises which were used by the PCF?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: If PCF gives up the premises and it is deemed that the premises ought to be used as an education centre, then it will be open to those approved foundations under the conditions which I have stipulated just now.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, does that mean that it will be by way of tender or by way of allocation by HDB?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: As I have explained, there are several conditions: (1) it must be a charitable foundation; (2) it must be registered under section 29 of the Companies Act; (3) it must have a minimum paid-up capital; and (4) it must be recommended by the Advisor to the CCC.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Does it mean that if an organisation fulfils the conditions mentioned by the Minister, HDB will give them automatic allocation?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Not necessarily, Mr Speaker. We have to find out how many education centres there are to provide enough places for the children. We do not just convert all the void decks into education centres for every applicant that comes around and qualifies. We must also have some planning norms on the number of education centres compared to the number of children in the area.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: If the premises become vacant, would the HDB consider tendering or letting out the premises to private organisations or charitable organisations?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am very glad that Mr Low Thia Khiang now talks in the same language of tendering out at market rates. But HDB believes that

Column: 517

education centres, being for education purposes, ought to be at a subsidised rate. Therefore, we would like to let them out to approved foundations.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Besides the PCF, so far, has any approved organisation been allocated premises by the HDB to run education centres at void decks?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: As far as I can recollect, none has applied.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Can I take it from the Minister that the rules are designed solely for the PCF to have the premises?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: The rules are rational and there is a basis for them. As I have explained, first, education centres are meant for education purposes. So HDB does this not at market rates. Unlike the Member, we do not believe in making profit out of education. Second, since it is not to be let out at market rates, we must find some way to allocate it. Since it is subsidised, it should be given to foundations which do this as part of their mission. Therefore, it must be an approved foundation. We want to have some certainty that the approved foundation can do the job well. It cannot be any fly-by-night foundation. So we stipulate a minimum paid-up capital of $5 million. At the same time, we want the Advisor to the CCC to understand all the facilities available in his constituency so that he can organise the facilities for his residents and constituents. So we also ask the Advisor to have a say in recommending the foundation for allocation of these premises.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Would the Minister say, based on the criteria he has set, that so far PCF is the sole organisation which has qualified and it is justifiable to have the privileged allocation from HDB to enjoy such subsidies?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: If no other charitable organisation, with these criteria, applies, how can I go and chase after them to apply? The only one that has applied is PCF and it is recommended by the Advisor to the CCC. So HDB allocates the premises.

Column: 518

HDB RESIDENTIAL/COMMERCIAL/INDUSTRIAL
PROPERTY
(Lowering of rental rate)


    4. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Acting Minister for National Development whether the Housing and Development Board will pass the savings from property tax reduction effective from 1st July 1994 to its tenants by lowering its current rental rate of residential, commercial and industrial property and, if not, why not.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Mr Speaker, Sir, the property tax reduction of 1% each year from 1994 to 1997 is meant to assist property owners to improve and upgrade their properties, and also to help absorb some of their operating costs. In the case of sold shops and flats, the lessees will enjoy this reduction.

    HDB's rental flats are let out at subsidised rates. The rents have not been raised since 1979. HDB has absorbed the higher operating costs over the years and has not passed on these costs to the tenants.

    The majority of HDB's rental shops and industrial properties are also let out at rents below the prevailing market rates. As such, HDB does not intend to lower its current rental rate for residential, commercial and industrial properties as a result of the 1% property tax reduction.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, I declare my interest because my company is a tenant in HDB industrial premises.

    Based on the answer given by the Minister, was it the interpretation of the Acting Minister that the intention of the Finance Minister, in announcing the reduction of property tax, was to help Government reduce expenditure on subsidies to industrial premises?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: The intention of the property tax reduction is, as I stated earlier, to help property owners, in this case, HDB, to improve and upgrade their properties and also to help them absorb some of the operating costs. In the case of HDB rental flats, the rent is kept very low. We do not see the need to reduce it by 1%. Similarly, for rental shops and industrial

Column: 519

premises, the rents are all below market price. If any tenant feels that he is not getting a fair deal from HDB, he can give up his premises and tender for new premises.

     Mr Chia Shi Teck (Nominated Member): Sir, has the valuation of HDB properties been increased over these years? If so, the 1% reduction is not enough to offset the increase in valuation.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: HDB's shops and industrial premises are let out on a term tenancy depending on the tenants. Some choose one-year tenancy while others choose two-or three-year tenancy. At the end of the tenancy, there will be a rental revision by 10%, 20% or 30% depending on the term of tenancy. Many of these premises are let out at very, very low rates because many of them were resettlement cases. So even if we adjust by 10-30% at the end of the term tenancy, the final rates are still very far below the market rates.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Just now, the Acting Minister mentioned that industrial and commercial premises are let out at below market price. How about tenders? The HDB puts out tenders and the tenants tender at market rates.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: That is correct. If the tenants obtain their shops in the first instance through tender they would have paid market rates for them. As willing buyer and willing seller, they sign for one-, two- or three-year tenancy at the rate that they want.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: So for these tenants who have tendered for their shops on the open market and paying market rate, would HDB consider giving them the reduction in property tax?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: The answer is no.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Why not? The rationale is that because it is below market rate, HDB will not give such a rebate. But in this case it is at market rate.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: HDB treats its properties, both rental flats and shops and

Column: 520

industrial premises, as a cost centre overall. I am sure all individual businessmen do not allocate cost to individual units.

GOVERNMENT/RESTRUCTURED HOSPITALS
(Occupancy rate of Class C beds)


    5. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for Health what is the occupancy rate of class C beds at government/restructured hospitals for the years 1985 to 1993.

     The Minister for Health (BG George Yong-Boon Yeo): Mr Speaker, Sir, occupancy rates of C class beds in public sector hospitals varied between 65% and 76% during 1985 to 1993.

    The bed occupancy rate for each year was as follows: 

                     1985           -           71%

                     1986           -           70%

                     1987           -           71%

                     1988           -           68%

                     1989           -           65%

                     1990           -           70%

                     1991           -           76%

                     1992           -           75%

                     1993           -           76%


     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Based on the occupancy rate, it seems to be quite consistent. But I note that the number of C class beds in the hospitals has been reduced over the corresponding period. Would the Minister make an assessment as to whether the number of C class beds in the hospitals now will be sufficient in future in view of the aging population?

     BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Yes, we will adjust the number to the demand required.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, do the hospitals keep records of daily occupancy rates of C class beds?

Column: 521



     BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: I am sure they do.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, is the Minister aware of any instance where a patient has been referred to a higher class bed because of the non-availability of Class C beds in the hospital?

     BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: If it happens on that day that the Class C beds are all taken up and the case is acute and the patient cannot be referred to another hospital with Class C beds available, then the patient will be admitted to a Class B2 bed but charged Class C rate.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, what is the number of Class C beds planned for the Tan Tock Seng and Kandang Kerbau Hospitals when they are completed?

     BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Sir, I do not have the numbers here. But if the Member will table another Question, I will be very pleased to give him the answers.

Column: 521

ALEXANDRA HOSPITAL
(Upgrading of facilities)


    6. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Minister for Health whether the facilities at Alexandra Hospital will be further upgraded and if the current services are adequate to meet the demand.

     BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Mr Speaker, Sir, the upgrading programme for Alexandra Hospital costing a total of $28.4 million commenced in early 1992 and is expected to be completed by the end of 1995.

    The upgrading works that have been completed to date include:-

    (a) Creation of a new Day Surgery Suite which has two Operating Theatres and 11 Day beds.

    (b) Renovation and upgrading of wards, Intensive Care Unit and four Major Operating Theatres. The wards are being renovated in stages. So far, the renovation works in six wards have been completed. The newly renovated wards have modern nurse call systems, piped-in medical gases, proper nurses stations, staff work areas and purpose-built isolation rooms.

Column: 522

The operating theatres are equipped with proper induction and post-operative recovery areas.

    (c) A Day Hospital for the elderly has been built and has started operation on 4th July 1994.

    (d) Road improvements for smoother vehicular traffic flow within the hospital, a second entry point into the hospital and additional car park lots for the public.

    Seven more wards and the Theatre Surgical Supplies Unit will be renovated. The X- ray Department is also being redeveloped, after which a Computerised Tomographic (CT) Scanner will be installed in early 1995. Lecture rooms and staff training facilities will also be provided.

    The current facilities and services are adequate to meet public demand. When the upgrading works are completed, Alexandra Hospital would have the facilities of a good secondary hospital.

     Dr S. Vasoo (Tanjong Pagar GRC): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister what would be the future of this hospital in view of the amount of resources that has been pumped into it to improve the facilities.

     BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: We intend to continue operating the hospital up to the early part of the next century. Beyond that, we have to study population patterns in Singapore and the need for additional hospital beds.

Column: 522

VICOM AND AUTOMOBILE ASSOCIATION
(Charges for second inspection of vehicles)


    7. Mr Cheo Chai Chen asked the Minister for Communications whether he will instruct VICOM and the Automobile Association not to charge $20.60 (GST included) for the second inspection of vehicles which have failed the initial inspection.

     The Minister for Communications (Mr Mah Bow Tan): Mr Speaker, Sir, under the Road Traffic (Motor Vehicles Test) Rules, the Registry of Vehicles sets the

Column: 523

maximum inspection fee which inspection centres can charge. Since 1982, this ceiling has been set at $40 for the first inspection and $20 for each subsequent inspection. The inspection fee of $20 for repeat inspections which VICOM and the Automobile Association introduced in January 1994 is in accordance with the limits set by ROV in 1982.

     Mr Cheo Chai Chen (Nee Soon Central): Sir, I think this is not reasonable, because sometimes small faults are not easy to detect. Only when you go to VICOM and AA for inspection that you could find out the faults.

     Mr Speaker: Order. Mr Cheo, are you making a speech?

     Mr Cheo Chai Chen: I am asking a question.

     Mr Speaker: Ask your question now.

     Mr Cheo Chai Chen: I have to say this first.

     Mr Speaker: No speeches. Ask your question. This is Question Time.

     Mr Cheo Chai Chen: I will ask the question now. Can I ask the Minister what is the reason for ROV to want these two organisations to charge for a second inspection?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: ROV did not ask these two organisations to charge. ROV has made provisions to set the limits so that organisations which are allowed to inspect vehicles, do not charge more than a certain limit. They have deemed it reasonable to set it at $40 for the first inspection and $20 for the second inspection. So long as these inspection centres do ot charge more than what has been prescribed, they are free to do so. It is not correct to say that ROV asked them to charge this amount. In fact, as I understand it, for many years, 1982 to 1994, these inspection centres did not charge anything for the second inspection. So I presume it must be because there are too many vehicles which are using the first inspection as their own quality check, and then coming back for the second

Column: 524

inspection. I presume this must be the case. Nevertheless, it is up to them whether they wish to charge or not.

     Mr Cheo Chai Chen: Sir, does the Minister agree that sometimes small faults are not easy to detect? So the vehicle owner has to send the vehicle for inspection and to be checked by more advanced equipment. Only then can they find out the faults. I think there should be no charge for the second inspection. I agree that maybe for the third inspection, the car owners should be charged.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: I suggest that the Member makes representations to the inspection centres not to charge for the second inspection. It is up to them whether they wish to take these views into consideration. As for the small vehicle owners not being able to detect the faults, I know that there are many vehicle owners who do not have to go for a second inspection. Presumably, they must have had other means of checking to make sure that their vehicles pass the first time.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, does the Minister have figures of how many vehicles passed the first inspection and the number of vehicles which needed subsequent inspections?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: No, I am afraid I do not have these figures offhand. If the Member would like to have these figures, I will be pleased to provide them.

Column: 524

FATAL MISHAPS IN SHIPYARDS AND CONSTRUCTION
SITES
(Preventive measures)


    8. Mr Chia Shi Teck asked the Minister for Labour (a) whether the many fatal mishaps in shipyards and construction sites were caused by human error and can be prevented; (b) whether the errors were committed by new and raw foreign workers; (c) whether all local and foreign workers of contractors and subcontractors have to undergo some stringent safety training before being assigned to work; and (d) what are his Ministry's plans to prevent or minimize such disasters.

Column: 525

ACCIDENTS IN SHIPYARDS
(Compliance with safety measures)


    9. Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon asked the Minister for Labour, in the light of the latest accident at the Sembawang Bethlehem Shipyard which resulted in loss of lives and injury of workers, in spite of industry reviews of safety systems and implementation of updated safety rules following previous accidents in other shipyards, what further steps his Ministry will take, together with shipyard managements and their contractors, to enforce compliance with safety measures.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Lee Yiok Seng) (for the Minister for Labour): Sir, may I have your permission to answer Questions 8 and 9 together because they are related?

     Mr Speaker: Yes.

     Mr Lee Yiok Seng: Sir, industrial accidents including those in shipyards and construction sites may be caused by many factors. Human error is certainly an important cause of such accidents.

    In fact, we have found that in many fatal accidents in shipyards and construction worksites, human error was a contributing factor. Such accidents could therefore have been prevented by workers and their supervisors being more safety conscious. For instance, in the case of the fire on board the "Stolt Spur", the chemical cleaning contractor chose to use improper equipment for cleaning the boiler. In the case of the "Indiana", the workers involved failed to ensure that their immediate work area was cleared of all flammable materials. As for the case of the "British Adventure", the senior technical personnel failed to take measures to isolate the power supply and close crucial valves before initiating hot-works on the hydraulic system.

    Sir, there is no conclusive evidence to show that inexperienced or new workers were largely responsible for the errors which led to the fatal accidents. Our records show that experienced workers are just as liable to commit errors and oversight. For instance, most of those who

Column: 526

failed to take precautionary measures and were found negligent by the Committees that inquired into the "Stolt Spur", "Indiana" and the "British Adventure" accidents were not inexperienced workers.

    Sir, all workers, including local and foreign workers, have to undergo a safety instruction course before they are allowed to work in shipyards. In addition, workers carrying out hot-works have to attend a special safety module which emphasises preventive measures on fires and explosions. The Ministry also conducts safety courses for Supervisors and Ship Repair Managers.

    As for the construction industry, all foreign workers are required to undergo a safety orientation course before they are issued with work permits. Contractors are also required to send their local workers to the course before work is allowed to commence at their worksites.

    In 1993, about 12,000 shipyard workers and 71,000 construction workers attended such courses.

    Sir, the Ministry has stepped up its efforts to prevent accidents in the shipyards and construction worksites since the spate of accidents in shipyards in 1992 and 1993. The Ministry is stringently enforcing the Factories (Shipbuilding & Ship-repairing) Regulations which incorporated all the safety measures recommended by the "Stolt Spur" and "Indiana" Committees of Inquiry. Apart from many new specific safety requirements, major shipyards are now required to have their safety management systems audited.

    The Ministry has also been mounting special enforcement exercises on shipyards. Those found violating safety rules were dealt with severely. Stop work orders were issued where a workplace was found to be grossly unsafe. Since January this year, 30 such orders have been issued.

    Besides taking stringent enforcement action, the Ministry will continue to work closely with shipyards' managements, their contractors and the unions to promote safety and prevent accidents in

Column: 527

shipyards. The Ministry, together with the Association of Singapore Marine Industry, the Singapore Institution of Safety Officers, and NTUC, is planning a workshop for next month to review safety management and audit system practised in the shipyards. Other similar workshops or seminars will be organised from time to time to review legislation requirements, safe work practices and safety management systems. We will make every effort to help the shipyards and their contractors to better understand their responsibilities in complying with regulations on safety in their workplace.

    Sir, stringent enforcement action will also be taken at construction worksites. The Ministry will amend the Factories (Building Operations & Works of Engineering Construction) Regulations to augment the safety and health provisions at construction worksites. Among other things, contractors will be required to have their safety management systems audited.

    The Ministry is currently taking action to amend the Factories Act to include more comprehensive provisions for the safety and health of workers. The maximum penalty for offences under the Act will be increased.

    The Ministry will continue to enforce safety regulations and provide safety training for workers, supervisors and managers in the construction and shipbuilding and repairing industries so as to improve safety at such workplaces.

     Mr Chia Shi Teck: Sir, would the Senior Parliamentary Secretary say that checking by the enforcement teams would be very effective and how many people are actually checking on worksites and the shipyards?

     Mr Lee Yiok Seng: Sir, we have regular checkings. As to the number of people who are actually doing the checking, it depends on the officers and the programme. We have a very thorough programme to go round and check every one of them. I assure the House that we are very conscious of the safety of the workers.

Column: 528



     Mr Chia Shi Teck: After so many accidents and all the reports and inquiries, there still seems to be very frequent repeats. That means the checking system should be stepped up. If they do not have enough staff, probably they should increase their staff.

     Mr Lee Yiok Seng: As I mentioned just now, human error is one of the important factors that causes fatal accidents.
